text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.1.24, Organization and Staffing, Large Business and International Division.
This section contains the functional statements and responsibilities of the offices within the Large Business and International Division.
) As of November

, LB&I disbanded the Assistant Deputy Commissioner International (ADCI) organization as a separate unit and realigned its work, as well as parts of the Treaty and Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO) and Withholding and Individual International Compliance (WIIC) Practice Areas. WIIC is now Withholding, Exchange and International Individual Compliance (WEIIC) and has received the Automatic Exchange of Information (AEOI) and Exchange of Information (EOI) programs that were housed in TTPO. Within TTPO, the Director, Treaty Administration position has been eliminated. The Treaty Administration function has moved to WEICC and has been renamed from Treaty Administration to Exchange and Offshore Strategy (EOS). Within WEIIC, there is a new Director of Field Operations (DFO), Exchange and Offshore Strategy, who will oversee EOI, JITSIC, Offshore Compliance Initiatives, Planning and Special Programs (PSP) operations and practice networks previously housed within WIIC. The DFO, Foreign Payments Practice (FPP) will receive the AEOI program and is renamed DFO, FPP and AEOI. TTPO will retain the Treaty Assistance and Interpretation Team (TAIT), which is reassigned under the Director, Advance Pricing and Mutual Agreement (APMA). (
) IRM
and following subsections regarding Program and Business Solutions (PBS) were updated to reﬂect recent organizational changes. (
) Because of the organizational changes described above, existing content was rearranged, obsolete content was removed and titles were updated. Other editorial changes were made as needed. (

As of November

, LB&I disbanded the Assistant Deputy Commissioner International (ADCI) organization as a separate unit and realigned its work, as well as parts of the Treaty and Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO) and Withholding and Individual International Compliance (WIIC) Practice Areas.

WIIC is now Withholding, Exchange and International Individual Compliance (WEIIC) and has received the Automatic Exchange of Information (AEOI) and Exchange of Information (EOI) programs that were housed in TTPO. Within TTPO, the Director, Treaty Administration position has been eliminated. The Treaty Administration function has moved to WEICC and has been renamed from Treaty Administration to Exchange and Offshore Strategy (EOS). Within WEIIC, there is a new Director of Field Operations (DFO), Exchange and Offshore Strategy, who will oversee EOI, JITSIC, Offshore Compliance Initiatives, Planning and Special Programs (PSP) operations and practice networks previously housed within WIIC. The DFO, Foreign Payments Practice (FPP) will receive the AEOI program and is renamed DFO, FPP and AEOI. TTPO will retain the Treaty Assistance and Interpretation Team (TAIT), which is reassigned under the Director, Advance Pricing and Mutual Agreement (APMA).
Because of the organizational changes described above, existing content was rearranged, obsolete content was removed and titles were updated. Other editorial changes were made as needed.

IRM 1.1.24 dated September 24, 2020 is superseded.

) The mission of the Large Business and International (LB&I) division is to provide large business and international taxpayers top quality service by helping them understand and meet their tax responsibilities and by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness to all. (
) LB&I serves C corporations, S corporations and partnerships with assets greater than $

million. These businesses typically employ large numbers of employees, deal with complicated issues involving tax law and accounting ciples, and conduct business in an expanding global environment. LB&I also serves U.S. citizens and residents with offshore activities and non-resident aliens with U.S. activities. (

) LB&I is organized into headquarters support functions and practice areas. Support functions use data analysis, portfolio and program management tech- niques to support LB&I’s activities. The practice areas provide pre-ﬁling, ﬁling, and post-ﬁling programs and activities for the LB&I taxpayer population. The practice areas also study compliance issues within their areas of expertise suggest campaigns to be included in the compliance plan. (

for a table of commonly used acronyms. (

) LB&I is a world-class organization responsive to the needs of our customers a global environment. We apply the tax laws with integrity and fairness using innovative approaches to customer service and compliance. Our highly skilled and engaged employees work in an environment of inclusion where each employee can make a maximum contribution to the mission of the team. (

) A core set of guiding principles provides the foundation for LB&I: a. Flexible well-trained workforce – LB&I cultivates an environment of continuous learning to support the workforce with focused training, foun- dational skillsets, specialized knowledge and dynamic tools. b. Optimal selection of work – LB&I uses data analytics and examiner feedback to select the best work with intended compliance outcomes. c. Tailored treatments – LB&I employs an integrated set of tailored treatment streams to maintain ﬂexibility to address current and emerging issues and to achieve desired compliance outcomes. d. Integrated feedback loop – LB&I continually collects and analyzes data and feedback to focus, plan and execute work, promote innovation, and implement feedback-based improvement. (

) The LB&I division commissioner is supervised by the IRS deputy commissioner for services and enforcement, and is responsible for the full range of planning, managing, directing and executing the global activities of LB&I, which are generally described in this section. (

Serves as the chief executive and advisor to the IRS Commissioner and all IRS functions on matters within his/her jurisdiction

) The role of the LB&I deputy division commissioner is to support the LB&I division commissioner in the accomplishment of the LB&I mission in the istration of corporate tax laws, regulations, and procedures in compliance activities. (

) The deputy division commissioner oversees LB&I operations, including those of practice areas and headquarters support functions. The directors of practice area and support functions report directly to the deputy division commissioner.

) The assistant deputy commissioner for compliance integration (ADCCI) reports directly to the LB&I deputy commissioner and is responsible for all ADCCI erations. ADCCI operations include Strategy, Policy and Governance; Data Solutions and Compliance Planning and Analytics.
) Strategy, Policy and Governance (
) The director of Strategy, Policy and Governance (SPG) reports directly to the ADCCI. (

) The mission of SPG is to support the deﬁnition, planning, analysis, and balancing of LB&I’s portfolio of programs; ensure the alignment of operations to LB&I’s strategic policies, goals, and objectives to deliver value-driven results (

) SPG policy teams are responsible for: • Applying a consistent approach to policy decisions for LB&I operations to ensure they align with LB&I strategic goals and objectives • Deﬁning and documenting LB&I policies and monitoring LB&I operations to assess adherence to LB&I policies and quality standards • Ensuring all policy decisions are coordinated/vetted with internal and external stakeholders as appropriate (
) SPG strategy and governance teams are responsible for: • Deﬁning LB&I’s portfolio and forward looking portfolio strategy (e.g., LB&I priorities and resource allocation approach)

) The Compliance Strategy Council (CSC) serves as the governing body over the identiﬁcation, selection, assignment and allocation of resources for all com- pliance and enforcement activities for LB&I taxpayers. To fulﬁll its roles and responsibilities in assisting the Council, SPG: a. Coordinates all CSC meetings b. Provides the CSC with the necessary tools to manage its inventory of campaigns and submissions c. Assists the CSC in monitoring the practice area’s execution and post- campaign activities d. oint site (

To fulﬁll its role and responsibilities in assisting the Council, SPG: a. Supports the deﬁnition, planning, analysis and balancing of LB&I’s portfolio b. Coordinates all CISC meetings c. Maintains the CISC website and Shar
oint site (

) SPG is responsible for the LB&I Fraud Program, collaborating with Office of Fraud Enforcement (OFE) and Criminal Investigation (CI) to inform and educate LB&I employees about the indicators of fraudulent tax practices by individuals, partnerships, and corporations and about the proper procedures follow once fraud is identiﬁed. The SPG fraud analyst reports on LB&I fraud results and collaborates with LB&I practice area fraud coordinators on fraud initiatives. See the LB&I Fraud Program website and IRM
for more infor- mation. (

) SPG is responsible for the LB&I Corporate Executive Compliance Program, informing and educating LB&I employees about their responsibilities for verifying that key officers and executives have ﬁled their income tax returns simultaneously with the examinations of LB&I corporate tax returns. In addition, LB&I employees are required to inspect and examine key officers and executive returns when warranted. See the LB&I Corporate Executive Compli- ance website for guidance and IRM Exhibit
for more information. (

) The Campaign Development and Administration (CD&A) program teams assist the practice areas in analyzing and scoping the identiﬁed compliance risks as- sociated with a campaign proposal. These program teams are comprised of technical employees and specialists who work closely with the practice areas to develop campaigns. CD&A is also responsible for developing ﬁlters and models used for workload selection, campaign monitoring and Content Man- agement Collaboration support. (

) The Whistleblower Claim for Reward Program may pay awards to people who provide speciﬁc and credible information to the IRS if the information results in the collection of taxes, penalties, interest or other amounts from the noncompliant taxpayer. The LB&I Whistleblower Team in Workload Develop- ment and Delivery works closely with the Whistleblower Office on all whistleblower claims involving an LB&I taxpayer. See the Knowledge Manage- ment LB&I Whistleblower Page for more information. (

) The mission of the Data and System Management (D&SM) group is to transform data into useful information and develop tools to support planning, risk analysis, decision- making and performance improvement for LB&I. D&SM delivers workload and provides related ﬁeld support throughout the case lifecycle. This includes: • Obtaining, managing and providing quality data for LB&I • Timely and efficiently delivering returns and related information to the ﬁeld • Providing ﬁeld support to enhance planning • Providing risk assessment and inventory management • Identifying ways to better leverage and more effectively use technology in the delivery of programs and services • Obtaining and using feedback from customers to improve processes and systems (

) D&SM services a wide variety of customers including the IRS research community, LB&I ﬁeld employees, LB&I executives, SB/SE division, Research- Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) and W&I division. (

) To accomplish the mission and serve these customers, this group acquires, validates and maintains tax data from LB&I returns and schedules LB&I uses for planning, risk analysis, return selection and issue identiﬁcation processes. D&SM provides database and systems management for multiple LB&I inventory management systems. Business (

PBS is responsible for the development, implementation and evaluation of policies, programs and services that meet LB&I’s unique strategic needs. Its functions include budget formulation and execution, workforce forecasting, re- cruitment planning and identiﬁcation, resolution of division-wide labor management issues, planning of organizational change efforts, training devel- opment and delivery, succession planning, as well as internal and external communications. PBS is also responsible for LB&I’s collaboration with IT to develop strategies, integrate technology and enhance business processes to improve LB&I’s ability to promote and enforce compliance with federal tax laws. PBS partners with other business operating divisions to deliver excellent customer service and products. (

) Resource Solutions (RS) partners with the Practice Areas to deliver quality communications, human resource, training, ﬁnance, and real estate programs, products, and services to support effective tax administration. (
) The RS organization is comprised of the director’s office and four subordinate organizations: • Communications • Human Capital Management • Finance • Learning and Education (

) Communications collaborates with each practice area to plan and produce written communications, presentations, multimedia, and more. They track external speaking engagements, facilitate virtual events, manage the Getting Right (GIRT) employee feedback tool, and coordinate visits from and provide official responses to foreign tax administrations. (

) Within Communications, the Web User Experience (UX) team manages content on the LB&I intranet and maintains LB&I-owned content on IRS.gov, while adhering to agency web standards. They also provide guidance on digital communications and web-centered technologies to improve upon the user ex- perience. (

) Human Capital Management (HCM) has three offices which oversee the devel- opment, implementation, and evaluation of human capital policies and programs. The offices plan and implement all hiring and staffing needs such initiating personnel actions. HCM oversees position management/classiﬁcation, performance management, awards, and staffing programs (i.e. telework, etc.). They also manage workforce planning and HR analytics to create solutions developed in partnership with stakeholders to resolve workforce concerns. HCM represents LB&I’s interests and serves as the liaison with HCO. (

) Finance has two sections which provide budget formulation, plan development, overall management and execution of the LB&I Financial Plan including tracking resource usage. Finance acts as the liaison between the division and IRS CFO and represents LB&I’s interests in the Division Finance Officers and Planning, Budgeting and Advisory Committee meetings. Finance also oversees the international travel process for the IRS. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Quality Review and Analysis (QRA) provides LB&I customers with an evalua- tion of case quality, identiﬁes best practices and makes recommendations quality improvements. QRA provides quality data and promotes consistency applying quality standards throughout LB&I examinations by evaluating a tistical sample of large business return and International Individual Compliance (IIC) cases for compliance with the audit and documentation requirements deﬁned in the IRM. (

) QRA is responsible for reporting overall quality score results from its case reviews using a Document Collection Instrument to reﬂect the adherence to auditing standards. The parameters of these reviews change as the workload demands of LB&I become more diversiﬁed. (

) LB&I is organized into eight practice areas. Five of the practice areas are issue-based: • Pass-Through Entities • Enterprise Activities • Cross-Border Activities • Withholding, Exchange and International Individual Compliance • Treaty and Transfer Pricing Operations The other three practice areas are geographically-based: • Western Compliance • Eastern Compliance • Northeastern Compliance (

) Global High Wealth (GHW) focuses compliance expertise on high wealth indi- viduals and the enterprises they control. High wealth individuals frequently operate complex enterprises consisting of multiple, interrelated businesses ﬂow-through entities and often have international components. The job of GHW is to take a uniﬁed look at the entire web of business entities controlled by a high wealth individual to assess the risk such arrangements pose to tax com- pliance and the integrity of our tax system. ) Financial intermediaries (FI) ensures that the withholding, reporting and depos- iting of tax for those foreign entities that have entered into withholding agreements with the IRS is conducted according to contractual requirements. These entities include qualiﬁed intermediaries, withholding foreign partnerships, withholding foreign trusts and qualiﬁed derivative dealers. FI provides support for the implementation of FATCA compliance strategies. (

establishes the guide- lines for the CWA program. (

) Automatic Exchange of Information (AEOI) (

) The AEOI program administers and coordinates all automatic exchanges of information between the U.S. and foreign national tax authorities (i.e., exchanges occurring on a regular and systematic basis, without the need for speciﬁc requests for information). (

) Automatic exchanges include exchanges of FATCA ﬁnancial account data, certain information related to the OECD’s Base Erosion and Proﬁt Shifting project (Country-by-Country Reporting), and information on U.S.-sourced ﬁxed determinable annual periodic (FDAP) payments to foreign persons and foreign- sourced FDAP payments to U.S. persons (traditional automatic). AEOI also coordinates activities with internal business units and foreign tax authorities with respect to FATCA intergovernmental agreements, conﬁdentiality and data safeguards and competent authority arrangements relating to AEOI.
) International Individual Compliance (

) IIC ﬁeld operations is comprised of groups of revenue agents, tax compliance officers and tax examiners that are responsible for administering tax compli- ance for U.S. citizens residing abroad or in U.S. territories and non-resident aliens who have a U.S. ﬁling requirement. IIC’s primary areas of responsibility include: a. Administration: IIC administers the tax law that affects any individual with international activity. These efforts include understanding our taxpayer population, proposing legislative changes, ensuring consistent treatment of similar taxpayers and promoting taxpayer education. b. Strategy Priority: IIC is responsible for developing strategies to address the highest priority issues within speciﬁc taxpayer segments. IIC coordi- nates with the other IRS business operating divisions to determine who best suited to address the issues found in speciﬁc taxpayer segments. c. Program Delivery: IIC’s day-to-day responsibilities include identifying risk returns and issues, case building, examining high risk returns, devel- oping training, educating the IRS workforce, and working with speciﬁc groups in a pre-ﬁling environment.

) The director of the Treaty and Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO) Practice Area reports directly to the LB&I deputy commissioner and is responsible for all TTPO operations. TTPO identiﬁes emerging tax treaty and transfer pricing issues and coordinates closely with LB&I leadership and Division and Associate Chief Counsel (International) to ensure consistently strong adminis- tration of treaty and transfer pricing issues throughout the IRS. TTPO also identiﬁes, leads and participates in LB&I campaign initiatives. (

) TTPO is responsible for transfer pricing tax compliance activities and has a treaty oversight role with regards to: • U.S. multinational enterprises • Foreign entities with U.S. operations and activities • U.S. citizens and residents residing outside of the U.S. • Offshore activities and non-resident aliens with U.S. business or invest- ment activities (
) The TTPO director is delegated authority under IRS Delegation Order
perform all functions as the U.S. Competent Authority for purposes of interna- tional tax agreements to which the United States is a party. (
) TTPO is comprised of the following programs: a. Advance Pricing and Mutual Agreement (APMA) b. Transfer Pricing Practice (TPP) (

) The Advance Pricing and Mutual Agreement (APMA) program resolves actual or potential transfer pricing disputes in cooperation with the taxpayer. APMA administers the Advance Pricing Agreement (APA) program, which provides voluntary process whereby the IRS and taxpayers may resolve transfer pricing issues and issues for which transfer pricing principles may be relevant on a Internal Revenue Manual

) Planning and Special Programs (PSP) is responsible for the identiﬁcation, clas- siﬁcation, risk assessment and return delivery of the IIC ﬁling population. It supports the ﬁeld teams with inventory and workﬂow by monitoring actual per- formance against the compliance plan and providing updates and status reports necessary to allocate time and resources properly. PSP responsibilities include:
Claims processing Compliance Functional Automation Support Exchange of Information Screening and Examination Fi

APMA also administers the portion of the office of the U.S. Competent Authority with responsibility for cases arising under the business proﬁts and associated enterprises articles of U.S. tax treaties. An example of competent authority issue handled by APMA is the double tax that could be incurred as a result of an allocation made by the IRS under IRC
or by a foreign tax authority under an equivalent provision in its domestic law. (

) In addition, APMA administers, through its TAIT function, the portion of the office of the U.S. Competent Authority with responsibility for issues arising under other articles of U.S. tax treaties, including instances of double taxation or taxation otherwise inconsistent with a tax treaty and requests for certain cretionary determinations. (

) TAIT is responsible for addressing all issues and cases related to the operation of tax treaties, excluding exchanges of information administered by EOI, AEOI or JITSIC, or issues pertaining to transfer pricing or other allocation cases ad- ministered by APMA. TAIT’s responsibilities include: a. Negotiating agreements with treaty partners under mutual agreement cedures to resolve taxpayer-speciﬁc cases and negotiating generally applicable arrangements with treaty partners to clarify the application or interpretation of tax treaty provisions b. Developing and managing the practice networks responsible for treaty and exchange of information issues commonly encountered in examina- tions c. Providing ﬁeld personnel with a central point of contact for addressing matters pertaining to tax treaties (other than issues arising under the as- sociated enterprises article or the business proﬁts article), including implementation of mutual agreements that affect taxpayers’ U.S. ﬁling requirements d. Developing training materials and delivering training programs for ﬁeld personnel e. Supporting the Treasury Department in negotiations of treaties/protocols and TIEAs f. Supporting Treasury and IRS initiatives relating to the OECD g. Overseeing the U.S. Territories program (
) The Treaties PN and EOI PN fall within TAIT and as such, report to the Director, APMA. Note: Although the EOI compliance function is within WEIIC, the EOI Practice Network is in TTPO. (

) The Treaties PN provides resources on how tax treaties may affect the taxing jurisdiction of each treaty partner by modifying the results that might otherwise be obtained under domestic law. ) TPP is comprised of a team of specialized transfer pricing professionals with ﬁeld examination focus. TPP may take primary responsibility for the examina- tion of transfer pricing issues on an income tax return or may provide guidance to a team of other agents performing the examination. As such, TPP duties include: a. Identifying appropriate transfer pricing issues and cases for audit b. Performing the appropriate analysis of issues or advising examination teams in this activity and determining the best transfer pricing method apply c. Developing the Service’s positions on transfer pricing issues and commu- nicating examination ﬁndings clearly and persuasively, both orally and writing d. Ensuring consistent and coordinated support of transfer pricing issues before Appeals, LB&I competent authority functions and, if necessary, litigation e. ) Pricing Practice (

) TPP also consists of the TPP PNs, which are groups of specialized profession- als that assist examiners by addressing and collaborating on compliance issues associated with income shifting, transfer pricing and valuation. The PNs also share knowledge, assess risks and work on special projects. (
) The TPP PNs consist of the following groups: a. Transfer Pricing Practice Network (TPPN) b. Transfer Pricing Risk Assessment (TPRA) team
) Pricing Practice (TPPN) (

) The TPPN provides a forum where issues, audit techniques and best can be shared and evaluated, fostering coordination and collaboration among all those interested. The TPPN serves as an engine for income shifting strategy, training and knowledge management. (

) The TPPN is comprised of revenue agents, tax law specialists and economists who provide guidance on various inbound and outbound income shifting issues, including transfer pricing, valuation and gain exportation and loss zation issues. The TPPN focuses on a wide range of controlled transactions that may facilitate income shifting between U.S. and foreign-related entities (i.e. controlled foreign corporations, controlled foreign partnerships and/or foreign parents) to lower-tax environments. (

) The TPPN addresses and develops training on a wide range of issues, including: • Tangible goods transactions • Intangibles and intangible property (IP) valuation • Services and cost allocations • Cost sharing agreements • Pricing ﬁnancial instruments
Pricing Risk Team (

) The TPRA team performs high-level risk assessment using data analytic niques to identify and evaluate transfer pricing risks. The TPRA team supports TTPO through project-focused risk assessment activities. Compliance (

) The director of Western Compliance Practice Area (WCPA) reports directly the LB&I deputy commissioner and is responsible for all WCPA operations. WCPA provides the full range of pre-ﬁling, ﬁling and post-ﬁling programs activities for large and mid-size businesses in Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Kansas, Louisiana, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Oregon, Texas, Utah, Washington and Wyoming. WCPA also has nationwide responsibility for the computer audit specialists.

) The Computer Audit Specialist (CAS) program is a component of the WCPA (DFO-South Central) within LB&I. The CAS program consists of computer specialists and statistical sampling coordinators. The computer audit specialists support examinations with analysis of electronic records. The statistical sampling coordinators support examinations with statistical samples as an effective audit technique. All business units within IRS are supported by the CAS program. (

) The director of the Eastern Compliance Practice Area (ECPA) reports directly to the LB&I deputy commissioner and is responsible for all ECPA operations. The ECPA provides the full range of pre-ﬁling and post-ﬁling programs and tivities for large and mid-size businesses in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee and Wisconsin. The ECPA has nationwide responsibility for the Compliance Assurance Process and has Servicewide responsibility for the gineering Program. (

) The Engineering Program provides expertise on numerous technical issues including research credit, depreciation, depletion and valuation. The technical experts have backgrounds in various engineering disciplines (e.g., petroleum, computer science and mining) and include individuals certiﬁed/licensed in business and real estate appraisal. Engineering and valuation teams can provide services on a consult or formal referral basis. (
) The primary function of the Engineering Program is to provide specialized services to ﬁeld personnel across multiple operating divisions as well as Appeals and Counsel. Assurance (

The Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) is a pre-ﬁling program, which began as a pilot in 2005. The program improves timeliness and efficiencies for both taxpayers and the IRS through a real-time review process to ensure taxpayer compliance. The program has three phases: CAP, Compliance Main- tenance (CM) and CM Bridge. CM was added in 2011 when the program became permanent. CM Bridge was added in 2019 when the program was revised.
